AI Stack at Lilly
The AI Stack at Lilly simplifies AI development with reusable, modular artificial intelligence (AI) components that can be easily integrated into various applications.
By leveraging reusable AI components, developers can save time and resources, ensuring consistency and reliability across projects. This approach accelerates innovation, as it allows teams to build complex AI systems efficiently without starting from scratch for each new project.

Intake Form
The AI Registry is Lilly’s centralized database for tracking risk assessment information on all AI systems. It promotes transparency, accountability, and regulation compliance while ensuring AI projects align with Lilly’s goals and ethical standards.
This form collects key details about your AI idea to assess its feasibility and potential risks related to AI in Technical, Legal, Privacy, Cybersecurity, and Quality areas.
Note:
Reviews take time. The more complete and detailed information you can provide upfront, the smoother and faster the assessment process will be for reviewers. Timely responses to any follow-up questions from reviewers are also critical to avoid delays.
Refer to the
Using AI Responsibly at Lilly procedure
and the
AI Guidelines
for guidance.
Register AI Idea
Need help?
Please review the
AI Registry FAQs
first for answers to common questions. If you still need assistance, click the chat icon in the bottom right or email
ai@lilly.com
.

AI Registry Review Process: What to Expect
Important:
This process reflects requirements for AI Registry submissions made on or after November 7, 2025. Submissions prior to November 7 will follow the review process based on the submission date. To use the new process, you can
submit a modification request
to:
Cancel and resubmit your use case
Request the Cybersecurity review be cancelled noting the
SAE request ID
Request the Privacy review be cancelled noting the Privacy request ID.
Your
AI use case
may be reviewed for:
Prioritization
Functional
Risk assessment
AI Tech
Legal
Quality
During the Risk assessment review, a Tech@Lilly partner will work with you to evaluate your use case against risk criteria (based on data, context of use, system, and vendor details per Global Digital Governance Committee (GDGC) guidelines) and confirm the appropriate review path. Use cases that meet the low-risk criteria will follow the Low Risk Fast Path, requiring only the following reviews.
Prioritization
Functional
Risk Assessment
* Quality reviews are only required if the AI is used in a GMP use case, if the AI uses continuous learning and the AI output impacts patient safety or product quality, or if the AI output is included in a Regulatory submission without 100% human review.
** AI recommendations are supplemental and do not replace required company processes, including
Privacy review
,
Cybersecurity review
, and
Working with Third Parties (WwTP)
. Vendor contracts must include standard AI language.
Review 1: Prioritization
Weekly review of new form submissions to determine next steps using the following evaluation criteria:
Should this be done?
Is the expected ROI sufficient?
Does this already exist or overlap with another program/product?
Does it align with business strategy?
Can it be funded and staffed across exploration, design, implementation, and support phases?
Review outcomes:
Proceed
– assign priority: Critical, High, Medium, or Low
Reject
– Rejected items may be resubmitted later with updated information
Review 2: Functional
A Tech@Lilly representative from the selected organization will contact you to:
Understand the use case
Ensure alignment with local strategy
Confirm if the need is already met
If it's a new, high-value opportunity, the local Tech@Lilly team will partner with you to determine an appropriate path forward, which may include prioritization and potential funding. A local architect may draft a technical design to guide the next steps.
Note:
Many ideas spend a lot of time here due to strategic or technical alignment considerations.
Review 3: Risk assessment
The Tech@Lilly lead architect for the requesting function connects with the submitter to fully understand the use case and proposed design.
Review includes:
Answering key questions covering data processed, context of use, architectural design, and vendor contract details.
Verifying and confirming all information in the AI Registry submission.
Possible outcomes:
Fast path review cycle
Standard review cycle (templated Legal guidance)
High Risk review cycle (full Legal review)
Review 4: AI Tech
Enterprise-wide technology AI experts review your proposed solution to:
Recommend the reuse of existing systems/vendors
Define architecture and models for new solutions
Identify and mitigate technical risks
Suggest testing and monitoring strategies
Review 5: Legal, and Quality (in parallel)
These reviews ensure your AI solution is:
Legally compliant
Protects personal and proprietary data
Meets quality standards
Reminders
Dev work (using green data only) can begin after the completion of the AI Tech review.
Work in QA/Prod or processing Lilly data through a vendor product cannot begin until all reviews are complete.
Reviews take time – your engagement makes a big difference!
Proactive teams respond to reviewers, clarify designs, and move quickly through approvals.
Unresponsive teams delay reviews and risk missing key milestones.
Start standard implementation processes early to accelerate the review cycle.
Work with your CSQ representative
Work with your
BISO
to complete the
Security Architecture and Engineering (SAE) process
Complete the
Privacy Review Process(lilly.com)
Complete WwTP and ensure vendor contracts contain AI wording

AI Registry Frequently Asked Questions
Why do we need an AI Registry?
expand accordion
The AI Registry is a centralized database that captures risk assessment information about all Lilly AI systems.  It enhances transparency, accountability, and compliance with regulatory requirements. It also helps manage risk and ensures that AI projects align with Lilly’s goals and ethical standards.
What types of AI projects should be included in the registry?
expand accordion
See the
AI Registry Submission Decision Tree
Who is responsible for maintaining the AI Registry?
expand accordion
The Advanced Intelligence team and stakeholders from Architecture, Legal, Cybersecurity, Privacy, and Quality are responsible for maintaining the registry. They ensure that the registry is up-to-date and that all AI projects are adequately documented.
Who can access the AI Registry?
expand accordion
Submitters or Custodians can see their use cases by going to the
Lilly Employee Center Portal
and choosing More > My AI Systems Submitted for Review in the top right.
All use cases can be viewed by stakeholders and risk assessors (Prioritization teams, Functional group members, AI Technical Reviewers, Cybersecurity, Legal, Privacy, and Quality).
AI Use Case Reports
Portfolio
:
High-level listing and summaries, and submitted AI Registry items
Operational
:
Metrics for review teams
If you need access to additional reports, please send an email to
ai_program_operations_team@lists.lilly.com
.
When should I submit a use case?
expand accordion
The AI Policy applies to any existing AI use case not yet reviewed per the
Using AI Responsibly at Lilly procedure
and the
AI Registry Decision Tree
.
For AI products, chatbots, or tools in use, check the AI Registry
portfolio reports
to confirm your use case is properly logged to meet legal and compliance requirements.
See the
AI Registry Submission Decision Tree
If you are working with a vendor who is using AI and all of these are true, then no AI Registry use case is required (globally, except China):
The AI does not process Lilly data or provide deliverables or services to Lilly (except for business productivity tools*)
No model training on behalf of or at the direction of Lilly
No integration with Lilly systems
No Lilly employees interacting with the system
MSA / contract contains AI terms (either updated MPT with AI terms or full AI Standard)
*Business productivity tools
include general-purpose AI assistants like Microsoft Copilot, Grammarly, or similar commercially available tools that vendors may choose to use in their own business operations to improve efficiency, draft communications, or perform routine tasks. Vendors may use these tools at their discretion provided they do not input any Lilly confidential information, proprietary data, or information subject to Lilly's data protection requirements into these systems.
Should I answer AI Registry questions based on the current state or the intended final use of the solution?
expand accordion
Reminder:  Use cases are expected to be submitted to the AI Registry multiple times as the use case proceeds through the
Innovation Stages
.
Fill out the registry with (1) the intended purpose of the system (e.g., this system will be used for clinical trial matching and will consume X data at launch) and (2) the current stage of development (e.g., we are operating in a dev environment with dummy (green) data).
Stage = Alpha
Data Classification = Green
Data Processed = None of the above
Audience = Lilly Employees
Then when the solution is fully defined and ready for development for production use,
a scope change to your original submission
must be submitted
for review with updated information.  (See “How do I resubmit a use case?” below)
Stage = Beta
Data Classification = Red
Data Processed = Personal Information (PI), Confidential Information (CI)
Audience = Patients (Commercial)
Do you have any guidance or examples of "good" AI use case submissions?
expand accordion
Check out these suggestions:
AI Submission Guide | Tech HQ
When should I resubmit a use case?
expand accordion
The AI product has changed scope from the original use case (e.g., If you have a new intended outcome, data collection, increased data classification, expanded the audience, added geographies, or technology changes such as a different vendor, model, or platform)
You did not receive guidance from legal.
The AI product is advancing Innovation Stage from Pre-Alpha or Alpha to Beta, Early Release, or General Release. Please see
Our Innovation Stages | Tech HQ
for definitions.
How do I resubmit a use case?
expand accordion
Either the submitter or custodian should go to
Intake Form | ai.lilly.com
and click the Register AI Idea button towards the bottom of that page to get the Intake Form.
Then on the first question, choose the scope change option and select the system from the drop-down menu. Include as many details as possible about what has changed from the previous submission. Reviewers will focus on what has changed since the previous review.
What reviews are included when I submit my use case?
expand accordion
See the
Process page
for a description of the Reviews.
Who do I contact for each review?
expand accordion
Local Functional Assessments based on supporting organization,
click here to view contacts
.
For Specialized AI Risk Assessments, see below.
AI Tech Review: Contact Malika Mahoui
Legal Review: Contact Emma LeMasters
Quality Review: Contact Rebecca Kitts
How long will it take for my use case to be reviewed?
expand accordion
The review timeline depends on several factors, including:
The maturity and completeness of the use case submission
The complexity of the AI system
Whether a new vendor or model is involved
The intended users of the AI system (who and where they are)
The input data sources
How the AI output will be used
You can track the status of each review in your AI Registry submission record
or in the
Lilly AI-Registry Portfolio
report listing
, which shows which reviews are complete and which are in progress.
Please note that while you may begin vendor contracting during the review process, your use case is not considered fully approved until all required reviewers have provided their sign-off. Reviews are prioritized first by any approved expedited requests, then by the Prioritization field.
We continue to improve the
AI Registry process
to make reviews as efficient as possible.
How do I cancel or modify an AI use case?
expand accordion
Use the
Submit Requests and Report Issues
link at the bottom of ai.lilly.com to request modification or cancellation of an AI use case. Include the AIR number, title of the use case, and the submitter’s name.
How do I see the status of my AI use case?
expand accordion
To see the status of your submission, access the
Lilly Employee Center Portal
, select More in the top right corner, and then select My AI Systems Submitted for Review.
You can also search the listing available in the
Portfolio
.
How do I see the status of a use case where I am not the submitter?
expand accordion
Search the listing available in the
Portfolio Reports
.
Do I need to register a chat assistant created with Chat in a Box, an Agent created with Copilot studio, or something created with Claude to the AI Registry?
expand accordion
Claude solutions, Chat in a Box, and Copilot Studio Agents are GenAI productivity tools for Lilly employees that typically
do not
need to be submitted to the AI Registry process. However, specific uses may require registration and review to ensure compliance with legal and information handling requirements.
✓
See the
AI Registry Submission Decision Tree
✓ Submit to the AI Registry
if your AI Assistant will be used for sensitive decisions (e.g., HR recruitment, drug discovery, patient support, regulatory compliance).
✓ Only share with authorized users
- Grant access only to users who already have permission to access the underlying data sources. Do not share with unauthorized
users.
Why are we managing AI risk differently than other System Risks?
expand accordion
Many factors contribute to the heightened concern over AI risks compared to other computer systems. AI has immense potential benefits, but so are the challenges and risks, making it crucial to approach AI development and deployment with caution and robust governance.
Autonomy and Decision-Making
: AI systems can make autonomous decisions without human intervention. This can lead to unintended consequences, especially if the AI’s decision-making process is not fully understood or transparent.
Complexity and Opacity:
AI models, particularly deep learning systems, are often complex and operate as “black boxes.” This lack of transparency makes it difficult to understand how they arrive at specific decisions, increasing the risk of errors and biases.
Rapid Self-Improvement
: Advanced AI systems have the potential to improve themselves rapidly. This could lead to scenarios where AI systems surpass human intelligence and control, posing significant risks if not properly managed.
Bias and Discrimination
: AI systems can perpetuate and even amplify existing biases in the data they are trained on. This can result in unfair and discriminatory outcomes, affecting various aspects of society.
Security and Privacy
: AI systems can be exploited for malicious purposes, such as spreading misinformation, facilitating cyberattacks, or invading privacy. Their ability to process and analyze vast amounts of data makes them powerful tools that can be misused.
Can I work in QA and PROD environments after completing the AI Tech review?
expand accordion
No, before going to QA or Production or processing data through a vendor tool, applicable processes must be complete. This includes all AI Registry reviews and any other company processes that should be undertaken, such as a
Quality Risk Assessment
, a
Cybersecurity review
, a
Privacy review
, and
WwTP
. Vendor contracts should include standard AI wording.
What can I do in DEV after completing the AI Tech review for my use case?
expand accordion
Once the AI Tech review is complete, you may begin development work using only green (non-sensitive, non-production) data in the DEV environment.
What happens if my use case was rejected?
expand accordion
Review the guidance provided by the assessor who rejected the use case.  If you are the submitter or custodian for the use case, you can make updates to the use case by clicking on the Intake form (go to
AI | ai.lilly.com
and click on the red “Register AI Idea” button at the top right of the page and choose Intake and click the Register AI Idea button towards the bottom of that page to get the Intake Form). Then on the first question, choose the option describing re-reviewing for a scope change and select your use case. Include as many details as possible about what has changed from the previous submission. Reviewers will focus on what has changed since the previous review.
In addition, submissions that have been Rejected or Deferred will be reviewed by the Tech Innovation Pipeline team for Innovation Potential.
Where should I go to submit a new tech innovation idea?
expand accordion
The
Tech Innovation Pipeline (TIP)
and
AI Registry (AIR)
are now combined into one streamlined
Tech@Lilly Innovation Portfolio
. You can explore insights in the
unified dashboard
.

All AI use cases must be registered and approved.

Lilly's AI Guidance
L
illy is dedicated to using AI responsibly and ethically. Before using AI in your work, please review Lilly’s AI guidance.
Using AI Responsibly at Lilly
As with all breakthrough technologies, there are risks and benefits to using AI. When used incorrectly, AI can produce biased or incorrect results.
Before using AI products, you must
read the procedure
and utilize the
guidelines
.
Read Procedure
Decision Tree for Submitting a Use Case to the AI Registry
Before using a new AI tool, please consult this decision tree to determine whether your use case requires a submission to the AI registry.
Try the Decision Tree
Guidelines for Use of AI-Generated Media (Images, Video, Audio)
When using AI to generate media (e.g., images, video, or audio) for your work at Lilly, you must follow guidance on the use and labeling of media. Make sure to read the guidance thoroughly before using AI-generated media.
Read the Guidance
Do
Do engage and ask questions when unsure of appropriate AI use.
Do verify outputs of AI for accuracy
Do know the data sources, including biases and limitations.
Do get help on AI contracts.
Don't
Don't use public AI tools outside of these guidelines to make logical decisions about low-risk use.
Don’t put in personal or confidential information unless approved by Lilly (e.g., Copilot with Bing is approved).
Don’t put intellectual property at risk.
Don’t enter into paid AI license agreements for company use.
Dos and Don’ts of Public AI Tools
AI presents unique risks and limitations to be used responsibly and effectively. We must protect the
Confidential Information
,
Personal Information
, intellectual property, and reputation of our Company.

Frequently Asked Questions
Given the change-making power and quick emergence of AI, it’s no wonder that everyone has questions. Below are answers to some of the most common questions about AI products at Lilly. If you have other questions, please feel free to
contact us
.
View AI Registry FAQs
View the full FAQ PDF
How can I access Claude at Lilly?
expand accordion
There are three ways to access Claude securely at Lilly, depending on your role and needs. All options are cleared for Red data and use the same underlying Claude language model.
Chat and Build with Claude through Lilly's Chat in a Box
- A secure, web-based option with the same Claude language model in an easy-to-use interface.
Who can access:
All Lilly employees and contractors (except China)
How to access:
Visit Chat in a Box - Claude
Best for:
Most Lilly users who need quick, reliable access the Claude AI model without advanced enterprise features
Chat and Build with Claude on Microsoft Copilot
- Access Claude through Copilot Researcher for deep research tasks or build custom agents in Copilot Studio using Claude Sonnet 4.5 or Claude Opus 4.1.
Who can access:
Microsoft 365 Copilot users
How to access:
Use Claude with Copilot Studio
Use Claude with Researcher in M365 Copilot
(Coming soon)
Claude Enterprise (Desktop & Web)
- Claude Enterprise is Anthropic's premium AI solution with advanced features including Projects for team collaboration, Skills for document creation, and Artifacts for interactive content.
While cleared for Red data, Claude Enterprise is not clear for Orange+ SPI.
Who can access:
Prioritized access for Lilly Research Labs (LRL) employees; all other requests depend on license availability
How to access:
LRL employees:
Request here
Non-LRL employees:
Request here
Following approval, access
via web
or by
downloading the Claude desktop app
Login with SSO by using your Lilly email address
Best for:
Users needing deep research and analysis, large context windows, or team collaboration capabilities
Support:
For general Claude questions,
visit their support pages
For training and how-tow guides, visit
Lilly's Enterprise Claude Training page
For Lilly-specific Claude questions, post in the
Claude Viva Engage community
To report an issue, contact
Claude@lilly.com
Is Enterprise Claude approved for CI and PI?
expand accordion
Yes,
Enterprise Claude
is approved for Personal Information (PI) and Confidential Information (CI). If you are unsure or have questions about data use with AI systems, use the
Privacy Help Desk Chat
or contact the
Digital Legal Office
.
Is Chat in a Box approved for CI and PI?
expand accordion
Yes,
Chat in a Box
is approved for Personal Information (PI) and Confidential Information (CI). If you are unsure or have questions about data use with AI systems, use the
Privacy Help Desk Chat
or contact the
Digital Legal Office
.
What is the scope of the Using AI Responsibly at Lilly Procedure?
expand accordion
The procedure applies to any product that fits the definition of "AI" (as defined in our procedure) without exceptions. Teams do not need separate submissions for each statistical analysis run on the AI model. The use case submission should cover the general data types and purposes for using the AI model. Note: Any scope changes, including using different data sets, will require a resubmission of the procedure for review.
What kind of impact can AI have on Team Lilly?
expand accordion
We are embracing AI as a transformative technology. AI will supercharge Team Lilly by allowing us to do our work better and faster. But we must all use it carefully and responsibly.
AI tools are helping us accelerate drug discovery, speed clinical trials, and improve the patient experience by improving how we work – employing algorithms to automate mundane, repetitive, and time-intensive tasks to improve the accuracy and speed of many of our processes – creating thousands of hours of capacity for our teams to focus on value-added work.
Many new or improved AI products will be released as part of our broader AI program. While some initiatives are specific to one group (e.g., scientists), others are for all employees. Our six-month beta release roadmap allows employees to begin trying out these AI products and provide feedback to help shape the future of technology at Lilly. Visit AI.Lilly.com to learn more.
How is technology – including AI – helping us to manage the best pipeline in the industry?
expand accordion
Technology is critical to our success as a company. In the clinical space, as our pipeline grows in size, complexity and value, the number of clinical studies is increasing each year. We are exploring how to leverage intelligent automation and GenAI to streamline and increase the speed of supporting our clinical trials.
We are leveraging a new AI-powered tool called Safety Automated Narrative Generator (SANG) to revolutionize the way Global Patient Safety (GPS) operates. SANG has the capability to automate the writing of patient safety narratives for regulatory submissions, ensuring our compliance with global regulatory agencies and that patients in need can maintain access to our medicines. When leveraged for the 250,000 narratives submitted by GPS each year, SANG can reduce the touch time for each case by up to 90%, saving more than $1 million annually and improving the consistency and accuracy of our narratives. This technology is one of our earliest applications of natural language generation and is an example of how AI is helping us work smarter and faster.
We’re also furthering the possibilities of connected clinical trial automation by licensing Magnol.AI’s capabilities to an external partner, ProofPilot. Magnol.AI is a wearable sensor data cloud that assists researchers with collecting, visualizing, and deriving critical insights from digital biomarker data. We have previously been leveraging this tool internally as a solution for remote data collection and digital biomarker development. But now, for the first time, this product will be used as a revenue generator for Lilly by licensing it externally.
Read more
on LillyNow.
With AI, we have new opportunities to harness our data on a real-time basis to improve information dissemination to HCPs (e.g., commercial and medical affairs) and help create frictionless experiences for people to start and stay on treatment.
Does our AI adoption strategy apply to affiliates outside the U.S.?
expand accordion
Everyone, including our OUS affiliates, can leverage AI by following the
Using AI Responsibly at Lilly procedure
and utilizing these
Guidelines for Responsible Use of Artificial Intelligence
. In fact, AI can be beneficial in cases such as
translating materials into local languages
.
What should I know about artificial intelligence (AI)?
expand accordion
AI is the field of computer science focused on creating intelligent machines that can perform tasks requiring human-like intelligence. Generative AI (GenAI) is the subset of AI focused on creating content as opposed to analyzing or predicting.
We continually develop new ways to apply AI and AI automation across Lilly, including new and improved products. We are grouping our practical applications of AI into four categories, with the first three as our emphasis:
Authoring
: AI generates first drafts of materials and hands them off to you.
Conversing
: You interact with AI in real-time to ask questions.
Copiloting:
AI operates in real-time alongside you, offering suggestions as you work
.
Monitoring:
AI runs independently and flags a human when needed.
Before using an AI product, you must read the
Using AI Responsibly at Lilly procedure
and utilize these
Guidelines for Responsible Use of Artificial Intelligence
. Only specific public AI tools, such as Copilot with Bing, are Lilly-approved to handle Personal and Confidential Information. Do not put any Personal (PI) or Confidential Information (CI) into a public AI tool until you have confirmed that it is approved for that information.
We are posting information and resources on
ai.lilly.com
and communicating through LillyNow articles, Viva Engage and email. We will continue to share information that showcases how AI can help us all work better and smarter. You can also submit a use
case
idea via
this form
.
What are the ethical considerations of using AI in our work?
expand accordion
While many GenAI models are trained on data publicly available on the Internet, some of that data may be questionable. Some AI-generated content
will
be inaccurate, so the expectation is that you verify the results. We must be careful to protect our intellectual property in using these technologies. It is vital that we follow the Red Book to demonstrate our commitment to integrity, and we are providing guidance that aligns with those values.
We are working to implement additional governance items that will further formalize the process to identify risks and position ourselves to continue working appropriately within our values. Continue to reference our Lilly guidance documents.
How does AI help Lilly accelerate reach and scale?
expand accordion
We are scaling our digital capabilities across the enterprise and applying the newest technologies to our vast data sets and scientific expertise. Our most powerful example at Lilly is what we refer to as
model-driven drug discovery
, utilizing GenAI with our proprietary library of millions of molecules and public data, enabling us to dream of new molecules and evaluate their potential faster than ever – at a previously unattainable scale. This will allow us to pursue more difficult diseases and biological targets and to discover new molecules that address serious unmet medical needs.
As we seek to accelerate reach and scale, we must launch our medicines globally – simultaneously. Traditionally, we would launch sequentially, starting in the United States, then Europe, Asia, etc. Another AI use case is using technology to evolve our intelligent content ecosystem strategy, helping us to develop and disseminate our marketing and promotional content to people faster. AI could also potentially accelerate our global claims process as well as our clinical trials.
How reliable is the output of Bing Chat, ChatGPT or other AI tools? Can we rely on the accuracy of the information?
expand accordion
Just like humans commit errors, AI tools can also output erroneous information. This is a phenomenon called “hallucination” where a large language model (LLM) used to build the tool perceives patterns that are nonexistent to humans, leading the tool to create outputs that are flawed or inaccurate. While AI technology will continue to become more accurate as tools are refined, every user of AI must apply the same rigor of quality checks to the outputs from AI as we would with outputs from humans.
You can learn more about the benefits and risks of using AI by reviewing the
Using AI Responsibly at Lilly procedure
and utilizing these
Guidelines for Responsible Use of Artificial Intelligence
.
How should employees leverage public GenAI tools like Copilot with Bing? Am I permitted to use AI-generated images at Lilly?
expand accordion
Following our guidelines, you are encouraged to find opportunities to safely and responsibly integrate AI into your work. Copilot with Bing is available on Lilly-issued laptops and iPhones.
We recently launched a beta version of a proprietary Lilly AI image generator for internal creative content. For information and guidance, refer to this
LillyNow article
.
Before using an AI-generated image, verify with leadership that it is appropriate for the task and complies with Lilly’s
Using AI Responsibly at Lilly procedure
and these
Guidelines for Responsible Use of Artificial Intelligence
. Always remember that you are responsible for the final output of your work. Reach out to the
AI Team
if you have any questions.
How can I determine the suitability of my use case and optimize tool usage?
expand accordion
Before using publicly available AI tools, please consult
this decision tree
to decide whether your use case is acceptable and how best to use the tool.
Our use of AI will impact our processes and people. How will you prepare the organization to continuously adapt and change? Will you be offering AI training for employees?
expand accordion
We will continue to share information showcasing how AI can help us all work smarter and provide employees with tools and technology to foster adoption and support through the change. This will be gradual; it will not happen overnight.
Training will be developed to educate and upskill Lilly employees. Tech@Lilly is also working to make sure training is part of large-scale rollouts. In the meantime, we encourage employees to try out the product available adhering to the
Using AI Responsibly at Lilly procedure
and utilizing these
Guidelines for Responsible Use of Artificial Intelligence
.
How can leaders empower teams to get upskilled on AI tools?
expand accordion
We have an ambitious agenda for AI at Lilly. To help with employee awareness and adoption of AI products, Ieaders should consider the following:
Establish the right AI culture:
Create an environment that encourages learning and innovation around AI. This can involve fostering a growth mindset, promoting curiosity, and providing opportunities for employees to safely explore and experiment with AI technologies.
Identify AI skill gaps:
Analyze your team’s current skillsets and identify areas where improvement is needed in AI adoption. This can help prioritize the skills to focus on and ensure that upskilling efforts are targeted and effective.
Educate on prompt criteria:
Prompts are the language of AI, ensure your team has the right resources to write effective prompts to maximize their experience using AI tools.
Recognize upskilling efforts:
Recognize employees who actively engage in AI-related upskilling activities.
As leadership understandably extols the significant gains made with AI, what are we doing to ensure we do not let bias and exclusion creep into our data? How are we ensuring equity and inclusion in AI-generated content?
expand accordion
It is important to note that every model will have some form of bias, so we will continually work to reduce it. New models that use any information about humans are evaluated as part of our AI governance process.
We also encourage employees to thoroughly review AI output for bias and accuracy. We are early in the learning curve for the use of AI, and through your feedback, you are helping to shape the future of AI at Lilly.
We share your desire to not have bias in our tool results, but it is recognized that AI models must be fine-tuned, as the data sources that feed tools are imperfect.
How are we ensuring that this technology is good for business while complying with all regulatory authorities? What are the potential risks to the company that we should all be aware of?
expand accordion
AI has many benefits, but if misused, it can create inaccurate, biased, or harmful results. It can also put privacy and intellectual property rights at risk.
Additionally, to ensure that the public AI we’re utilizing or the proprietary AI we’re developing is good for the business while being compliant with all regulatory and legal authorities governing our industry, we are working to create an Accountable AI policy that includes clear expectations for appropriate use of these technologies.
For more information, refer to the
Using AI Responsibly at Lilly procedure
and
Guidelines for Responsible Use of Artificial Intelligence
.
Where can employees find guidance on testing and verifying AI outputs?
expand accordion
Employees can refer to internal
training materials
and
guidelines
on AI usage, which provide specific recommendations for testing, verifying, and ensuring the reliability of AI outputs in different operational contexts.
What are the dos and don’ts when using public AI tools?
expand accordion
AI presents unique risks and limitations to be used responsibly and effectively. We must protect the
Confidential Information(CI)
,
Personal Information(PI)
, intellectual property, and reputation of our Company by following these dos and don’ts:
Do
Do engage and ask questions when unsure of appropriate AI use.
Do verify outputs of AI for accuracy.
Do know the data sources, including biases and limitations.
Do get help on AI contracts.
Don’t
Don’t use public AI tools outside of these guidelines to make logical decisions about low-risk use.
Don’t put in personal or confidential information unless approved by Lilly (e.g., Copilot with Bing is approved).
Don’t put intellectual property at risk.
Don’t enter into paid AI license agreements for company use.
What are the guidelines for using AI image generation at Lilly?
expand accordion
When using AI to generate images for your work at Lilly, you must follow guidance on how to use and label these images. Make sure to read
Lilly Guidelines for Use of AI-Generated Media (Image, Video, Audio)
before using AI imagery.
How does AI affect healthcare, and what precautions should be taken?
expand accordion
AI holds tremendous promise for the future of healthcare. Because of the sensitive and important nature of our work, there are additional considerations to make before using AI. Learn more about how AI can impact our industry and the special precautions we must take by accessing
this link
.
What are the validation requirements for AI projects?
expand accordion
Please access
LQP302-30
: Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning (AI/ML) Computer System Validation for requirements.
What does leadership expect from me when it comes to AI? Will AI take my job?
expand accordion
The most significant risk we face when it comes to AI is doing nothing at all. These tools are here to make your lives easier and free up your time to do higher-level thinking – so take advantage of them! With the world of GenAI, we no longer have to start with a blank page: have the machine generate a first draft, and you become the editor. This will require a shift in mindset and approach and will take time. The best thing you can do is explore how the tools can work for you and share learnings back with your teammates.
How do we ensure we have the right data pipeline to build an “AI Factory” at Lilly?
expand accordion
The AI and Enterprise Data Teams as well as others are working closely together on the foundational set of capabilities that will begin to form the "AI Factory". The Enterprise Data Backbone (EDB) is a key component for GenAI models to execute against. Getting high-quality data into the EDB is essential. Data that are accessible and consumable via the Marketplace (data.lilly.com) helps enable AI use cases and ensures we have the "right data" for a particular use case.
Are there scenarios where you’re considering an AI solution but haven’t fully defined the requirements?
expand accordion
Collaborate with your local Tech@Lilly resource to submit your idea to the
Technical Innovation Pipeline
.
Does your Tech@Lilly team require access to an AI platform sandbox?
expand accordion
Complete and submit the
AI Hub Sandbox Request form
to request Azure OpenAI sandbox access.
When should AI usage be disclosed?
expand accordion
In general, employees should disclose their use of AI unless it is an ancillary or productivity tool such as Copilot with Bing, Copilot for M365, or LillyTranslate. Individuals can use these tools to draft emails, translate documents, or use AI copiloting for internal documents and presentations. All other uses of AI tools should be disclosed.
Can you provide examples of when disclosure is necessary?
expand accordion
Disclosing
the use of AI
is necessary for any AI-generated content intended for external audiences, including marketing materials, publications, and social media posts. Disclosing
an interaction with AI
is necessary if you are developing or deploying a chatbot, summarization and analysis tool, or other AI-enabled systems that provide output to users. This type of disclosure
informs users
that they are interacting with an AI system and are responsible for verifying outputs.
What are some specific examples of when disclosure is required?
expand accordion
External-facing uses where AI-generated content might be employed include customer-facing communications, public presentations, and any content or tools intended for distribution outside our organization. Disclosure is also required internally if individuals use AI output to make decisions. For example, a chatbot that guides Lilly procedures requires disclosure to the end user that they are interacting with an AI chatbot and responsible for verifying outputs.
How will we clarify when disclosure is appropriate?
expand accordion
When in doubt, disclose.
Refer to the AI guidance on ai.lilly.com or contact the AI team at
ai@lilly.com
if you have additional questions on when disclosure is necessary.
Why is there ambiguity in the current language about disclosure?
expand accordion
The ambiguity intentionally allows flexibility depending on the context of AI use. However, we acknowledge the need for clarity and will provide concrete examples to guide appropriate disclosure practices.
What should I do if I am unsure whether disclosure is needed?
expand accordion
When in doubt, disclose.
Consider whether individuals outside of our organization will see the content generated with AI tools. If yes, disclosure is likely required; if no, disclosure may not be necessary. If you are unsure or have questions, contact the
Digital Legal Office
.
Where can I find more information about AI usage and disclosure?
expand accordion
Our internal policy documents and training materials will provide detailed guidelines and examples to ensure a consistent understanding and application of disclosure requirements.
How will employees know when they use AI and must follow procedure requirements?
expand accordion
Employees should generally rely on system disclosures to identify AI usage that requires adherence to procedure requirements. Suppose the AI features are integrated into existing Lilly tools or are not overtly apparent to users (e.g., background statistical models). In that case, they are typically considered low-risk and previously approved by Lilly.
What if an employee is unaware they are using AI due to recent tool updates or integration?
expand accordion
Employees are expected to follow procedure requirements for any AI integrated into enterprise-wide tools, even if unaware of its presence. Lilly ensures the system will flag any AI requiring disclosure when user awareness is necessary.
How does Lilly determine when AI use should be disclosed to users?
expand accordion
AI use requiring disclosure is generally flagged by the system to ensure employees are aware. This includes scenarios where AI significantly impacts or generates content that may affect external stakeholders or compliance.
What types of AI usage are exempt from explicit disclosure requirements?
expand accordion
Low-risk AI functionalities, such as background statistical models or integrated features within existing tools, are typically exempt from explicit user disclosure unless they significantly alter user interactions or outcomes.
Where can employees find more information about AI disclosures and requirements?
expand accordion
Internal policy documents and training materials provide guidelines and examples regarding AI usage and disclosure requirements. Employees are encouraged to consult these resources for clarity on compliance expectations related to AI utilization.
How much testing and verification should an employee perform before trusting the accuracy of an AI tool?
expand accordion
There are no strict rules, but employees should initially compare AI outputs with results obtained through their traditional methods for completing tasks without AI. They should do this multiple times to ensure consistency. Once confident in the reliability of the AI outputs, employees should continue to review results for any anomalies.
What should employees do if AI outputs show inconsistent or outlier responses during testing?
expand accordion
Employees should exercise caution if AI outputs consistently differ significantly from expected results or show outlier responses. It's advisable not to rely on such outputs until consistency and accuracy can be verified through further testing or adjustments.
Are there specific guidelines for determining when AI outputs are trustworthy?
expand accordion
A practical guideline is whether employees could comfortably share their methodology (prompts used to generate AI outputs) with supervisors or the public. If not, it suggests additional verification to ensure the credibility and accuracy of AI usage.

What is Copilot Chat for Work?
Copilot Chat for Work
is a versatile product that integrates seamlessly with a wide range of Microsoft 365 applications, including Word, Excel, PowerPoint, Outlook, Teams, among others. It serves as a valuable assistant, offering suggestions, corrections, and completions to enhance your productivity. Copilot can also generate fresh content tailored to your input. Copilot is your AI assistant
.
How do I get started with Copilot Chat for Work?
Discover Copilot Everywhere:
Access Copilot in
Outlook
,
Teams
,
Word
,
PowerPoint
,
Excel
, and more by clicking the Copilot logo.
Explore the Capabilities:
Learn about Copilot’s capabilities on the
Microsoft Copilot Community resource site
.
Engage and Learn:
Join the
Microsoft Copilot Community on Viva Engage
to participate in the conversation, read testimonials from Lilly employees, and discover helpful tips.
Why use Copilot Chat for Work?
Unleash Creativity:
Copilot is your tool for effortless generation of content, ideas, and insights. Whether you’re drafting documents, creating presentations, or composing emails, Copilot streamlines the process, letting your creativity flourish.
Unlock Productivity:
Bid farewell to routine tasks! Copilot is your time-saver, taking care of the heavy lifting. It’s akin to having a dependable AI aid that boosts your productivity, allowing you to concentrate on what’s important.
Uplevel Skills:
Seamlessly integrated into your everyday apps, Copilot promotes collaboration and aids in skill enhancement. With its responsible and secure AI, Copilot transforms your work approach, making every task more efficient and enjoyable.
What can I do with Copilot Chat for Work?
Copilot in Outlook:
Efficient Email Composition:
Copilot assists in drafting emails, suggesting revisions, translating messages, and providing direct coaching to improve emails before sending.
Summarized Emails:
Quickly understand the context of messages, clear and concise summaries of long discussions, and grasp the main point without reading the entire email conversation.
Copilot in Teams:
Real-time Assistance:
Copilot Chat uses your available Lilly Microsoft 365 content to answer questions, suggest ideas, summarize your workday, generate new content, summarize documents, and compare multiple documents quickly.
Meeting Insights:
During meetings, Copilot can generate summaries of topics, decisions, and action items, as well as help those who miss all or part of a meeting stay informed.
Copilot in Word and PowerPoint:
Enhance Writing:
Copilot assists you in drafting documents and presentations. It suggests relevant content, refines language, and even generates creative ideas.
Automate Formatting:
Copilot streamlines formatting tasks, ensuring consistent styles, headings, and layouts.
Copilot in Excel:
Data Analysis:
Copilot helps you analyze data, create formulas, and generate charts. It simplifies complex calculations and provides insights.
Assisted Data Organization:
Copilot can automate repetitive tasks, such as data cleaning, sorting, and pivot table creation.

How does Copilot Chat for Work protect Lilly’s data?

Lilly’s user's and business data in Copilot Chat for Work is protected and will not leak outside Lilly. Microsoft does not save the chat data and Microsoft has no eyes or access to Lilly's data. Lilly's chat data is also not used to train the underlying models.

.

Copilot Chat for Web searches the web to provide answers from anywhere. Copilot Chat for Work is integrated into your M365 to assist you with your internal work.

Additional Frequently Asked Questions on Copilot Chat for Work can be accessed
here
.

Guidelines for Use of AI-Generated Media (Images, Video, Audio)
Confirm Suitability
Ensure that use of AI-generated media (e.g., images, video, or audio) is appropriate for your task, and that such use complies with Lilly’s guidelines on Artificial Intelligence.
AI Tool Registry Requirements
AI-generated media created with approved media generation products (e.g., Lilly Image Generator, Copilot, Adobe) does not need to go through the AI registry.
Any AI tools that have not been previously approved must complete the AI registry process before use.
Don’t Input Personal or Confidential Information​
Limit inputs to “green” information. Neither Personal Information (such as patient identifying information) nor Confidential Information (such as Lilly business information or trade secrets) should be used as part of any AI input without express approval from the AI Team, except when using Enterprise Lilly AI tools that have been specifically vetted and authorized for handling such data. Using Personal or Confidential information in AI prompts exposes the company to the risk that such information is shared or mistakenly depicted in outputs. See footnotes below for more examples of Personal and Confidential Information.
Personal Information is any information that, when used alone or in combination with other information, identifies a person (such as a consumer, patient, job applicant, employee, health care professional, or trial participant). Examples of Personal Information include but are not limited to: names, dates of birth, identifying characteristics (gender, race, marital status), SSN or other government identifiers, biometric identifiers, consuming/ purchasing information, education, criminal records, employment details, financial information, medical/health information, location data, contact information, and protected characteristics. See
Personal Information Classification Chart
.
Confidential Information is any information not in the public domain, such as information relating to the Company’s products, business, or activities, including but not limited to: trade secrets, product research and development, client lists, unpublished patent applications, existing and future product designs and schematics, pre-launch medical device drawings and models, unpublished financial statements and earnings release statements and related work papers, pricing strategies, manufacturing strategy information, policies and local SOPs and processes, user IDs, and organizational charts. See
Protecting Confidential Information Global Procedure
.
Consult Third Party Agreements for AI Inputs
Agreements to which Lilly is a party may restrict the use of certain information in AI inputs, particularly where AI is being used to modify existing media licensed from another company. If you believe your use case may be subject to a third-party agreement (including, but not limited to, patient consent forms, model releases, or terms of service for use of third tools), consult the applicable agreement and the AI Legal Team for guidance.
Be Aware of IP Implications
Consult the AI Team before using AI media generation tools to generate output that Lilly may wish to protect with intellectual property (IP) protections, such as copyright, trademark, or patent. Likewise, do not use inputs that Lilly may wish to protect with IP, or that are already IP-protected, without express written authorization from the AI Legal Team. Additionally, ensure that the inputs used to generate media do not direct the media generation technology to copy existing work or generate outputs in the "style" of others. For example, users should not ask for images of a "dog" in the style of "Snoopy."
Provide Transparent AI Media Notices
When using AI to generate media for your work at Lilly, whether internal or external, please follow these instructions on the identification and labeling of AI-generated media. Remember that the general Lilly Guidelines for Use of AI-Generated Media apply to all AI-generated media.
When AI Disclaimers Are REQUIRED
AI disclaimers are required when AI-generated content could mislead viewers about
what they're seeing, such as realistic patient depictions, treatment outcomes, or other content that viewers might reasonably mistake for real people or real results.
The key question when determining if an AI disclaimer is required is whether a reasonable consumer would be misled by the AI-generated portion of the content absent a disclaimer.
AI disclaimers
may be required
when:
AI-generated media depicts humans (real or synthetic) including AI-generated synthetic performers in advertisements, identifiable landmarks, patients, or healthcare settings where viewers might reasonably believe the content is real
Content could be mistaken for authentic images, video, or audio recordings
AI has been used to materially modify media in ways that could mislead viewers, or where human modifications to AI-generated media could be mistaken for actual changes in a person’s condition (e.g., using AI to remove visible skin conditions or symptoms from a real patient's photo to depict treatment effectiveness)
When AI Disclaimers Are NOT Required
All disclaimers are
NOT required
for:
Decorative backgrounds, abstract patterns, or generic settings
Cosmetic edits to actors that viewers understand are not real patients
Stock imagery-style content unrelated to product claims
Content where AI use is obvious or doesn't impact product representations
Base media containing humans or identifiable landmarks (e.g., the Empire State Building) that are not AI-generated and where the AI content is not used to modify the human or landmark (a notice may be placed at the bottom of the page or tactic instead)
Standard Disclaimer Language
For unmodified AI-generated content:
"AI Generated”
Or "AI Generated [Image/Video/Voice/Audio]" (for images, videos or audio content)
For human-modified AI content:
"Some Content Generated by AI"
Or "Some Media Generated by AI"
Disclaimer Format Requirements
The notice should be:
Prominent and legible
for the intended audience
In clear and readable text and format
(not black text on dark background)
Included on the media itself wherever possible or immediately adjacent
For videos: overlay text, watermarks, or credits
For audio: verbal disclaimers at beginning/end, or visual notices when presented with visual materials
Multiple AI-Generated Materials on One Page:
For pages with
multiple AI-generated materials,
use of a
page-level disclaimer may be appropriate (e.g., "This Material Contains AI-Generated Images/Videos/Audio Content").
Content Identifiers
Built-in AI content identifiers (e.g., Adobe Content Credentials, Meta AI Info labels, Google watermarking) should be utilized when available but
do not replace required visible disclaimers
, as these metadata tags and watermarks are typically invisible to users in normal viewing circumstances and only accessible through active investigation such as checking image properties or using specialized detection tools.
Review Output
Remember that you are responsible for the final output you use in your work. Before using any AI-generated media or content, review the output to ensure that it is accurate, conveys your intended message(s), and is not false, misleading, or unduly risky to the company. Using AI-generated media that resembles identifiable individuals, mimics the style of an artist or creator, or involves the depiction of children carries a higher risk to the company than other outputs. If your AI-generated media will be used externally, conduct a quick Google search to see if anything similar is found. If so, consult with the AI Office.
Remember Our Reputation
Evaluate outputs from an outsider’s perspective and consider how both inputs and the media they generate may reflect Lilly’s reputation. AI-generated media and content should not be utilized if their use could negatively impact Lilly’s reputation.
Comply with Other Applicable Policies/Procedures
Remember to consult any Lilly policies that may apply to the AI-generated content and your intended use, and ensure that AI-generated media goes through the normal approval processes (e.g., Lilly brand guidelines, medical/legal/regulatory review).
Re-Evaluate Future Use
AI media and content generation technology may produce varied results even when the same input is used repeatedly. Thus, each output should be evaluated in accordance with the guidance provided above, even if the input has produced policy-compliant results in the past.
Raise Questions
If you have questions regarding this set of guidelines or your use of AI to generate media, or if you become aware or suspect that media or content generated by AI and utilized in Lilly work product does not comply with Lilly’s or third-party providers’ (e.g., Stability AI) policies, immediately reach out to the AI Office.

2025 AI UPSKILLING FOR TECH@LILLY LEADERS
GOAL: DEVELOP CORE SKILLS IN AI, ML, AND GENERATIVE AI TO STRENGTHEN TECHNICAL LEADERSHIP AND ACCELERATE THE DEVELOPMENT OF INNOVATIVE AI-DRIVEN SOLUTIONS, ULTIMATELY ADVANCING GROWTH AND IMPROVING PATIENT OUTCOMES.
Tech@Lilly leaders (M+, P5+, R7+) must complete the Tech@Lilly AI Certification Learning Journey Program for Leaders in SuccessFactors by
August 31, 2025
.
STEP 1: PREPARE
Here are recommended resources from AWS and Azure, including courses, studying materials, and practice exams to help you with certification.
Most learners need 1-3 months to prepare
. Certification is required on only one platform (AWS or Azure). The choice is yours.
AIF-C01: AWS Certified AI Practitioner
This link includes courses, a practice exam, and other prep resources available in Percipio.
AWS Certified AI Practitioner
This link offers an exam guide, official practice questions, free training, and more.
AWS Skills Builder
This link offers free resources, just use SSO and your Lilly credentials.
AWS Bootcamp Recording
Miss the April 2 AWS Bootcamp by Skillsoft? No problem—you can now watch it on demand to support your exam prep.
AIF-C01 Cert Prep
Prepare for the AIF-C01 exam with this LinkedIn Learning course.
AI-900: Azure AI Fundamentals
This link includes courses, a practice exam, and other prep resources available in Percipio.
Microsoft Certified: Azure AI Fundamentals
This link on Microsoft Learn offers skill details, self-paced content, free practice assessments, and more.
Study Guide
You can refer to the Microsoft study for exam AI-900.
Enterprise Skills Initiative portal (ESI)
This link provides digital learning, instructor-led courses, and practice exams. Log in with your Lilly credentials and search for AI-900 to find classes in your preferred language and time zone.
Guide to Prepare for the AI-900 Exam
Prepare for the Azure AI Fundamentals certification examination with this book.
There are three options for AI certification in Cybersecurity:
AWS Certified AI Practitioner (AF-C01)
AI-900: Azure AI Fundamentals
Certified AI Security Fundamentals (CAISF)
It's a 2-day course covering AI security basics and how to identify and mitigate AI-related risks. It includes lectures, discussions, hands-on workshops, and project-based learning for both theoretical and practical insights.
Tonex website
This site provides enrollment details, including schedules, fees, and registration.
STEP 2: PRACTICE
Consistent practice helps you identify and improve weak areas. To ensure thorough preparation, many practice resources are available for AWS and Azure certifications.
AWS
AWS Certified AI Practitioner Exam Prep
AWS Certified AI Practitioner Bootcamp
AZURE
AI-900: Microsoft Azure AI Fundamentals Practice Test
Microsoft Azure Fundamentals Bootcamp
STEP 3: TAKE
Choose the
Microsoft Azure AI Fundamentals
or the
AWS Certified AI Practitioner
exam. Exam funding is local.
STEP 4: UPLOAD
Once certified, upload your certification to
Workday
to showcase your achievement and inspire others to do the same.
STEP 5: SHARE
Share your certification in the
Tech@Lilly Leadership Community
on Viva Engage. Inspire others and highlight the possibilities of continuous learning.
Frequently Asked Questions
What is the AI Ascend program?
expand accordion
The AI Ascend program is designed to enhance knowledge and capabilities across the organization. In 2025, it will focus on AI upskilling within Tech@Lilly.
What is the purpose of the AI certification for leaders?
expand accordion
The AI certification for leaders aims to strengthen technical leadership and accelerate the development of innovative AI-driven solutions, ultimately advancing growth and improving patient outcomes.
Who is required to complete the AI certification?
expand accordion
Leaders at M+, P5+, and R7+ levels must complete one of the specified AI certifications by July 30, 2025.
What are the available AI certifications for leaders?
expand accordion
Leaders can choose between the
Microsoft Azure AI Fundamentals (AI-900)
or the
AWS Certified AI Practitioner (AF-C01)
certifications, with the exception of cybersecurity leaders, who can choose between the
Microsoft Azure AI Fundamentals (AI-900)
, the
AWS Certified AI Practitioner (AF-C01)
certifications, or the
Certified AI Security Fundamentals (CAISF)
.
When is the deadline for completing the AI certification?
expand accordion
The deadline for Tech@Lilly leaders to complete the AI certification is August 31, 2025. This deadline is earlier than last year’s Cloud Fundamentals Certification deadline. Completion of the certification will be reviewed during August Performance Management check-ins.
When will the AI certification completion be reviewed?
expand accordion
The completion of the AI certification will be reviewed during the August 2025 Performance Management check-ins.
What happens when a new hire joins Tech@Lilly between now and August 31?
expand accordion
If a new Tech@Lilly employee is onboarded who meets the assignment criteria, they will get the AI Certification assigned to their training plan. They will have 158 days from their hire/start date to complete the certification.
How do we pay for the certification exam?
expand accordion
You should use your Lilly corporate credit card to pay for the exam and submit for reimbursement.
Can anyone in Tech@Lilly take the AI Certification, or is it only reimbursable for leaders?
expand accordion
Anyone in Tech@Lilly can take the AI Certification with management approval.
Should I get the Microsoft Cloud certification before working on Microsoft AI?
expand accordion
Cloud certification isn’t required, but it can help familiarize you with Azure services.
Is it better to stick with the same cloud platform for AI certification as the foundational certification?
expand accordion
It’s not necessary to stick with the same cloud platform for AI certification. While staying with one platform can deepen your expertise, switching platforms can expand your knowledge, especially for multi-cloud environments. Choose the platform most relevant to your business area.
How long is my AI certification valid?
expand accordion
The
AWS Certified AI Practitioner (AF-C01)
is valid for
3 years
.
The
Microsoft Azure AI Fundamentals (AI-900)
certification
does not expire
.
Tip:
Add your certification to
Percipio
to get automatic renewal reminders.
